The catalytic activity for the selective catalytic reduction of NO x with NH3 (NH3-SCR) decreased in the order of 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC >4Ce/Ti-PILC >2V4Ce/Ti-PILC >1V/Ti-PILC >1V4Ce/Clay > Ti-PILC > Clay, with the 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC sample exhibiting the best activity (NO x conversion >90% at 280–450°C). Physiochemical properties of the samples were investigated by means of XRD, N2 absorption-desorption, SEM, H2-TPR, NH3-TPD, XPS, and in situ DRIFT techniques. The vanadia was uniformly dispersed on the Ti-PILC support, while the ceria were mainly present in CeO2. The Ti-pillared support was suitable for dispersing the V-Ce composite oxides. The strong interaction between vanadia and ceria led to increased H2 consumption and high-temperature reduction. The Ce4+/Ce3+ and V5+/V4+ redox cycle (V4+ +Ce4+ ↔V5+ +Ce3+) accounted for the excellent NH3-SCR catalytic performance of the 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC sample. The doping of a proper amount of vanadia could promote formation of Ce3+ on the surface of 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC, and the formed Ce3+ could generate a more amount of the chemisorbed oxygen species that favored the NH3-SCR reaction. Furthermore, the 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC sample possessed high catalytic acidity and strong NH3 adsorption ability, which were responsible for high NO conversion in a wide range of temperatures. The NH3-SCR reaction on the 4Ce/Ti-PILC and 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC samples obeyed the Langmuir–Hinshelwood (L–H) and Eley-Rideal (E–R) mechanisms, with the former being dominant. Keywords Ti-pillared clay V-Ce mixed oxide NH3-SCR In situ DRIFT Reaction mechanism 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NO x , i.e., NO, NO2, and N2O) resulting from various combustion processes are major causes of acid rain, ozone depletion, photochemical smog and respiratory system deconstruction [1,2]. The selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NO with NH3 has been employed for reduction of NO x emissions from stationary sources (such as oil, gas, and coal-fired power plants) [3,4]. The general reaction is: 4NH3 +4NO+O2 →4N2 +6H2O. As the most widely used commercial catalyst, V2O5-WO3(MoO3)/TiO2 exhibits good catalytic efficiency in the SCR reaction, but its narrow window of operation temperature (300–400°C) and toxicity of vanadia to the environment and human health as well as the easy oxidation of SO2 to SO3 at high temperatures pose a barrier to further applications [5,6]. Therefore, the design and development of novel NH3-SCR catalysts with reduced use of vanadia and high activity are of great practical significance. Owing to the redox property of Ce4+/Ce3+ and the oxygen defects, ceria has remarkable oxygen storage capacity, and hence is an appropriate candidate in catalyzing NO reduction by NH3 [7,8]. Currently, the Ce-based catalysts (e.g., CeO2/TiO2 [9], CeO2−MoO3/TiO2 [10], and CeO2−WO3/TiO2 [11]) have been found to show excellent SCR activity for the abatement of NO x . Considering the important role of V2O5 in removing NO x , a V-based catalyst is ideally chosen as the reference for the SCR of NO with NH3. Liu et al. [12] reported the improved activity and alkali-resistance after the addition of Ce to V2O5/TiO2, and found that the redox cycle (V4+ +Ce4+ ↔V5+ +Ce3+) could account for good performance for the NH3-SCR reaction of the 0.5% V2O5–5% CeO2/TiO2 catalyst. Considering that synergetic interactions of various compositions are closely related to the NH3-SCR performance [12], the combination of only V2O5 and CeO2 is expected to show the excellent SCR performance due to co-presence of the redox couples of Ce4+/Ce3+ and V5+/V4+. Pillared interlayered clays (PILC) are two-dimensional layered materials, and have been recognized as promising catalyst supports in the SCR reaction due to their large specific surface areas, acidity, high thermal stability, and low cost [13]. Yang et al. [14] synthesized a series of pillared clay-based catalysts (Al2O3-PILC, Fe2O3-PILC, Cr2O3-PILC, ZrO2-PILC, and TiO2-PILC) for the SCR of NOx with NH3, and observed that these pillared clay-based catalysts showed higher activities than the traditional V2O5-based catalysts in the temperature range of 250–450°C. Chae et al. [15] reported that the V2O5/Ti-PILC samples exhibited catalytic activities superior to those of the conventional V2O5/TiO2 and V2O5/Al2O3 catalysts for the NH3-SCR reaction. In this paper, the V-Ce/Ti-PILC composite catalysts were prepared using Ti-pillared clay (Ti-PILC) as support and V-Ce oxides as active component, and the effect of V-Ce loadings on the activity of the V-Ce/Ti-PILC catalysts for NH3-SCR of NO was studied. The relationship between physicochemical property and activity of the catalysts and possible reaction mechanisms were investigated by means of various techniques. The most significant finding of the present work is the development of a novel low-vanadia, high activity NH3-SCR catalyst in a wider temperature window. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Titanium-pillared montmorillonite support The raw montmorillonite was obtained from Shandong Huawei Bentonite Group Limited Company, China. The chemical composition of the montmorillonite was 73.2wt% SiO2, 17.2wt% Al2O3, 4.3wt% MgO, 2.3wt% Fe2O3, 2.0wt% CaO, 0.48wt%K2O, 0.24wt% Na2O, and trace amounts of other compounds, which was measured by the X-ray fluorescence (XRF) spectroscopic technique. The raw montmorillonite was acid-leached according to the procedure described elsewhere [16]. The proper amounts of acid-treated montmorillonite was dispersed in deionized water and the slurry was stirred for 24h. The ion-exchange solution was prepared by slowly adding tetrabutyl titanate (Ti(OC4H9)4, 99+ %, Alfa) to HCl aqueous solution under vigorous stirring. The Ti(OC4H9)4 and HCl (H+/Ti molar ratio=2.5) were achieved by adding the desired amounts of deionized water. The mixed solution was stirred for 12h and aged at room temperature (RT) for 12h. The obtained solution was added dropwise to the vigorously stirred montmorillonite suspension until the Ti/clay ratio reached 12.5mmolTi/gclay. The resulting solution was stirred for 12h and aged at RT for 12h. After that, the product was washed, dried at 100°C for 12h, and calcined at 400°C for 2h, thus obtaining the titanium-pillared montmorillonite (denoted as Ti-PILC) support. 2.1.2 Titanium-pillared clay-supported vanadium-cerium mixed oxides The 4Ce/Ti-PILC (the weight percentage of Ce (i.e., Ce/(Ce+Ti-PILC)) was 4wt%) sample was prepared by impregnating Ti-PILC with a suitable amount of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O. After stirring for 1h, the suspension was evaporated at 60°C using a rotary vacuum evaporator. Then, the obtained material was then dried at 100°C for 12h and calcined in air at 400°C for 2h. The 1V/Ti-PILC (the weight percentage of V (i.e., V/(V+Ti-PILC)) was 1wt%) catalyst was prepared by impregnating Ti-PILC with suitable amounts of ammonium metavanadate and oxalic acid aqueous solutions, and the subsequent preparation procedures were the same as described above. The yV4Ce/Ti-PILC (the “y” represents the weight percentage (wt%) of V (i.e., V/(V+Ce+Ti-PILC))) samples were prepared by impregnating 4Ce/TiO2-PILC powders with an oxalic acid-added NH4VO3 aqueous solution, and the subsequent preparation procedures were the same as described above. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The crystal phases of the samples were measured by the powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) on a Bruker D8 advance diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ=0.15406nm) at a scan ramp of 0.02°/s. BET surface areas of the samples were measured using N2 adsorption–desorption at −196°C on a JW-BK132F apparatus, each sample was degassed at 200°C for 6h under the vacuum condition before the BET measurements. Surface morphologies and elemental analysis of the samples were investigated by a scanning electron microscopy (SEM, SU-8010, HITACHI, Japan) with energy disperse spectroscopic (EDS, X-MAX,OXFORD, UK). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopic (XPS, ESCALAB 250Xi, Thermo Fisher, America) was used to analyze the chemical states of the samples, using Al Kα radiation as excitation source. The binding energy from adventitious carbon (binding energy=284.6eV) was used as a standard for binding energy calibration. The chemical analysis of the samples was carried out on the energy-dispersive X-ray fluorescence (EDXRF) spectrometer (Panalitical Magix, PW2403, Netherlands) with a rhodium tube as radiation source. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) experiments were conducted on a chemical adsorption analyzer (PCA-1200, Builder, China). About 100mg of the sample was placed in a U-shaped quartz tube, then pretreated in a flow (30mL/min) of 5 vol% O2 +95 vol% N2 at 400°C for 1h. The CuO sample (Aldrich, 99.995%) was used as a calibrated standard sample. Ammonia temperature- programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) experiments were carried out on a Builder PCA-1200 analyzer. The catalyst (100mg) was pretreated at 400°C and saturated with NH3 (30mL/min) at 100°C. After being purged with pure He at 100°C for 1h, NH3 desorption was conducted in a flow of He in the temperature range of 30–600°C at a heating rate of 10°C/min. In-situ DRIFTS experiment was carried out on a Bruker TENSOR II spectrometer characterized with a reaction chamber that could bear high temperatures (Harrick Praying Mantis). For each of the DRIFTS experiments, the catalyst (60mg) was placed in the sample cup of the reaction chamber. Before cooling to 30°C, the catalyst was pretreated at 400°C in N2 for 0.5h. In the experiments of NH3 and NO+O2 adsorption, the spectra were measured by means of subtracting the background spectra, which were recorded by exposing the samples to pure N2 at a flow rate of 100mL/min. NH3 adsorption was performed in a flow of 100mL/min, in which NH3 was 1100ppm with N2 as balance gas. NO+O2 adsorption spectra were recorded in a 100mL/min flow of 1000ppm NO+4 vol% O2 +N2 (balance). 2.3 NH3-SCR and NH3 oxidation Catalytic activities of the samples were evaluated using a quartz tubular fixed-bed microreactor. The NH3-SCR reaction was carried out in the microreactor by mixing 300mg of the catalyst with 300mg of quartz sands. The simulated exhaust gas was composed of 1100ppm NH3 +1000ppm NO+4 vol% O2 +5.0 vol% H2O+N2 (balance) and the total gas flow rate was 500mL/min. The concentration of NO was measured by a MODEL1080 analyser. The NH3 oxidation reaction was carried out in the microreactor by mixing 50mg of the catalyst with 150mg of quartz sands. The simulated exhaust gas was composed of 1100ppm NH3 +4.0 vol% O2 +N2 (balance) and the total gas flow rate was 100mL/min. The effluent NH3 concentration was measured on a Bruker TENSOR II spectrometer with a heating gas cell of 1.5m. All of the gas lines in the reaction system were heated to 150°C to prevent the possible condensation. The spectra were obtained in a continuous mode in the range of 600−4000cm−1, with an acquisition of 32 scans per spectrum, a spectrum resolution of 4cm−1, and a time interval of 120s. The NO and NH3 conversions were calculated according to their concentrations before and after the catalyst bed at a steady state, as shown in Eqs. (1) and (2): (1) NO conversion ( % ) = [ NO ] in - [ NO ] out [ NO ] in × 100 % (2) NH 3 conversion ( % ) = [ N H 3 ] i n - [ NH 3 ] out [ N H 3 ] i n × 100 % 3 Results 3.1 NH3-SCR activity Fig. 1 shows the catalytic activities of the raw clay montmorillonite, Ti-PILC, 4Ce/Ti-PILC, 1V/Ti-PILC, yV4Ce/Ti-PILC, and 1V4Ce/Clay for the NH3-SCR of NO. It is seen that NO conversion over all of the catalysts obviously increased with the rise in temperature from 120 to 400°C, but gradually decreased with temperature rise from 400 to 480°C. This phenomenon was caused by NH3 over-oxidization (as confirmed by the results shown in Section 3.2). Only 14% NO conversion was obtained at 400°C over the raw clay montmorillonite (Fig. 1a). The titanium-pillared clay (Fig. 1b), however, exhibited higher NO conversions in the whole range of temperatures. Such an improvement in activity could be attributed to the increase in acidity (as demonstrated in Section 3.7), which was one of the key features of ammonia adsorption for the SCR reaction. After loading 4wt% Ce on the Ti-PILC support (Fig. 1c), NO conversion over 4Ce/Ti-PILC increased significantly with the rise in temperature and more than 80% of NO was converted in the range of 280–450°C. On the other hand, for only vanadia-loaded sample (Fig. 1d), similar trend also observed over the 1V/Ti-PILC sample. Nevertheless, compared to the 4Ce/Ti-PILC sample, the 1V/Ti-PILC sample exhibited lower NO conversions (below 70% even at 450°C). This result suggests that the loading of Ce exerted a remarkable influence on catalytic activity. The catalytic activity of the co-loaded yV4Ce/Ti-PILC samples with different V contents are shown in Fig. 1e and f. Obviously, catalytic activity of the yV4Ce/Ti-PILC gradually decreased with the rise in V loading from 1 to 2wt%. Among all of the samples, 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC exhibited the best catalytic performance: almost more than 90% of NO conversion in a wide temperature range of 280–450°C (NO conversion still reached 90% at 450°C). This result indicates that the co-existence of V and Ce contributed to the improvement in SCR activity. To better evaluate the effect of Ti, the Ti-free 1V4Ce/Clay sample was prepared. Obviously, this Ti-free sample exhibited a lower catalytic activity (Fig. 1g, only 28% NO conversion at 400°C) than the 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC sample. Therefore, Ti was beneficial for enhancing the activity of the samples for the NH3-SCR reaction. The intrinsic catalytic activities in terms of the specific reaction rate at 300°C (r cat (molNO/(gcat s)) of our catalysts for the reduction of NO were compared with those of the catalysts reported in the literature [17–20], as summarized in Table 1 . It is observed that the r cat (3.41×10−8 molNO/(gcat s)) of the Clay sample and the r cat (2.05×10−7 molNO/(gcat s)) of the Ti-PILC sample were higher than the r cat (7.10×10−10 molNO/(gcat s)) of the TiO2 reported by Xu et al. [9]. Moreover, addition of V and Ce to Ti-PILC significantly increased the catalytic performance for NO reduction. The r cat (1.07×10−6 molNO/(gcat s)) of the 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC catalysts was also higher than the r cat (1.10×10−7–1.01×10−6 molNO/(gcat s)) of the V/Ce catalysts reported by other authors [12,17–20]. These results indicate that 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC exhibited better catalytic activity than the other V/Ce catalysts. Obviously, the r cat for the SCR reaction decreased in the order of 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC >4Ce/Ti-PILC >2V4Ce/Ti-PILC >1V/Ti-PILC >1V4Ce/Clay > Clay, which was in good agreement with the change trend in catalytic activity. 3.2 NH3 oxidation Fig. 2 shows the NH3 conversions over Ti-PILC, 4Ce/Ti-PILC and yV4Ce/Ti-PILC for the NH3-SCR reaction. No significant NH3 conversions over Ti-PILC were detected below 500°C (Fig. 2b). Over the 4Ce/Ti-PILC sample (Fig. 2c), NH3 oxidation started at 350°C, NH3 conversion increased with the rise in temperature, and 55% NH3 conversion was achieved at 500°C, accompanying by a significant increase in NO concentration from 7 to 65ppm (as shown in inset of Fig. 2). Compared with the NH3 conversion and NO concentration over 4Ce/Ti-PILC, those over yV4Ce/Ti-PILC (Fig. 2e-f) decreased significantly in the whole temperature range. This finding suggests the presence of a strong interaction between vanadia and ceria that could inhibit the oxidation of NH3. Among all of the samples, NH3 conversion and NO concentration over the 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC sample were the lowest, a result possibly due to the weakening of NH3 oxidation by the strong vanadia–ceria interaction. Therefore, the increased NH3 conversion and NO concentration in NH3 oxidation could explain the drop in NO conversion in the above SCR reaction. 3.3 XRD characterization Fig. 3 shows the XRD patterns of the raw clay montmorillonite, Ti-PILC, and supported V and/or Ce samples. It is observed that the XRD reflection peaks of each sample were at 2θ =19.8°, 26.6°, 28°, and 34.9°, which were characteristic diffraction signals of montmorillonite [16,21]. This result indicates that the structure of montmorillonite was not destroyed after Ti-exchange and Ce and/or V loading. For the montmorillonite sample (Fig. 3a), the high-intensity basal (001) reflection peak at 2θ =9.2° (lattice spacing=ca. 0.96nm) was obvious, indicating the order of the clay layers [22]. For the Ti-PILC sample (Fig. 3b), the (001) reflection in the position typical of montmorillonite did not disappear. A low-intensity and broad peak with a lattice spacing of 1.40nm appeared in the position (2θ =6.4°), suggesting an increase in interlayer distance due to the pillaring process. Moreover, there was additional diffraction peak at 2θ =25.3°, which could be assigned to the phase of TiO2. Therefore, a part of Ti-poly cations were successfully introduced into the interlayer space of montmorillonite. There were characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ =33.1°, 47.5°, and 56.4° assignable to cubic CeO2 [23] in the 4Ce/Ti-PILC, 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC, 2V4Ce/Ti-PILC, and 1V4Ce/Clay samples (Fig. 3c and e–g). In the meanwhile, no XRD peaks of vanadia-related crystalline compounds were detected in the V-loaded samples (Fig. 3d–g), indicating that the V species were highly dispersed on the Ti-PILC support. 3.4 Porous structure and surface area The nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms of the raw clay montmorillonite and as-prepared samples are shown in Fig. 4 . It can be seen that the isotherm of each sample was nearly type I in the relative pressure range (p/p 0) of 0.02–0.45 according to the BDDT classification, which was characteristic of microporous materials [24]. It can be seen that the adsorbed volumes of the pillared materials increased significantly in the p/p 0 (<0.01) range. The results suggest that a considerable amount of micropores were generated during the pillaring process and the TiO2 was successfully pillared in the interlayers of the clay. With the rise in vanadia loading, however, the adsorption volume gradually decreased, with the adsorption volume of 2V4Ce/Ti-PILC being the lowest. On the other hand, when the p/p 0 increased to 0.45–1.0, all of the samples showed a type H4 hysteresis loop, indicating that the layered structure was preserved and the typical micropores were slit-like [25]. The BET surface areas of the samples are summarized in Table 2 . The surface area of Ti-PILC obtained after calcination at 450°C was 168m2/g, whereas that of the raw clay was only 48m2/g. The increase in surface area of Ti-PILC indicates the successful pillaring of the Ti species into the silicate layers of the clay. It was worth noting that loading ceria or vanadia on the surface of Ti-PILC gradually decreased the surface area due to the possible blocking of partial micropores by vanadia and/or ceria [26]. The BET surface area increased in the sequence of 1V4Ce/Clay (28m2/g)< Clay (48m2/g)<2V4Ce/Ti-PILC (135m2/g)<1V4Ce/Ti-PILC (147m2/g)<4Ce/Ti-PILC (151m2/g)<1V/Ti-PILC (159m2/g)< Ti-PILC (168m2/g), differing from the order of catalytic activity (as shown in the above section). Therefore, BET surface area was not a key factor influencing the catalytic activity of the V-Ce/Ti-PILC samples for the NH3-SCR reaction. 3.5 SEM characterization Fig. 5 shows the SEM images of the Clay, Ti-PILC, 4Ce/Ti-PILC 1V/Ti-PILC, and 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC samples. It is observed that the Clay exhibited a flaky surface (Fig. 5a) similar to a loose sponge layer. After pillared with Ti, the Ti-PILC sample displayed disaggregation of the lamellar portions, generating an interlayer structure (Fig. 5b). For the 4Ce/Ti-PILC sample (Fig. 5c), the interlayer structure became less distinct after Ce loading on the Ti-PILC surface. There were some crystalline particles on the 4Ce/Ti-PILC surface, which might be due to the uneven distribution of Ce elements and the formation of crystalline particles (as shown in the EDS spectrum below). In addition, it could be also observed that the interlayer structure became less pronounced after loading of Ce and/or V on the support surface (Fig. 5(c–e)). To investigate the element distributions in the samples, the EDS analysis of the Ti-PILC, 4Ce/Ti-PILC, 1V/Ti-PILC and 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC samples was performed within a scanning range by random and the results are shown in Fig. 6 . Two random regions were selected to measure the regional element concentrations of each sample (Fig. 5(b–e)), as summarized in Table 3 . It can be realized that the Ti contents of the Ti-PILC sample in regions A and B (Fig. 5b) were 10.41 and 10.63, respectively, which were almost equal, indicating uniform distributions of the Ti element in the particles. For the 4Ce/Ti-PILC (Fig. 5c) sample, however, the Ce contents in regions C and D were 6.34 and 3.99, respectively, indicative of uneven Ce distributions in the particles. It might be possible that formation of the CeO2 crystalline particles on the 4Ce/Ti-PILC surface led to the uneven distribution of Ce element. For the 1V/Ti-PILC sample (Fig. 5d), the V contents in regions E and F were 0.15 and 0.07, respectively. This indicates that V was also unevenly distributed on the surface of 1V/Ti-PILC. It should be noted that the above similar scenario also occurred in the 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC sample (Fig. 5e). 3.6 H2-TPR The reducibility of a catalyst can be effectively evaluated using the H2-TPR technique. The TPR profiles of the samples are illustrated in Fig. 7 , and the peak positions and hydrogen consumption after quantitative analysis on the TPR peaks are listed in Table 2. For the raw clay montmorillonite (Fig. 7a), the TPR profile of montmorillonite displayed only one big peak (starting at ca. 500°C and centered at 700°C) and its H2 consumption was 0.22mmol/g. Such a H2 consumption was mainly due to the reduction of the iron species (2.3wt% in content) in the clay. In the case of the Ti-pillared clay, the reduction profile of the Ti-PILC sample exhibited two well-defined peaks at 580 and 710°C (Fig. 7b). The peak at 580°C was due to the reduction of the iron species, whereas the one at 710°C was attributed to the reduction of titania [27]. The reduction temperature (580°C) of the iron species in the Ti-pillared clay sample was much lower than that (700°C) of the iron species in montmorillonite, indicating that the Ti-pillaring process increased the reducibility of the montmorillonite clay. Additionally, the H2 consumption of the Ti-PILC sample was 0.19mmol/g, slightly lower than that (0.22mmol/g) of the montmorillonite clay. This result suggests that the presence of a strong interaction between TiO2 and clay could prohibit the reducibility of the iron oxide and titania species. For the 4Ce/Ti-PILC sample, three main reduction peaks at ca. 435, 520, and 710°C were distinguished (Fig. 7c). The first peak at ca. 435°C was attributed to the reduction of the surface oxygen of ceria, the second peak at ca. 520°C arose from the overlapping reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+ and iron species in the sample [28], and the low-intensity and broad peak at 710°C was assigned to the reduction of titania. The reduction profile of the 1V/Ti-PILC sample exhibited two reduction peaks at 530 and 710°C (Fig. 7d). The peak at 530°C was ascribed to the overlapping reduction of V5+ in vanadia and iron species, whereas the one at 710°C was due to the reduction of titania [27,29]. The TPR profiles of the yV4Ce/Ti-PILC samples with different vanadia contents are shown in Fig. 7e and f. Obviously, the yV4Ce/Ti-PILC samples exhibited higher reduction temperatures and H2 consumption as compared to the 4Ce/Ti-PILC or 1V/Ti-PILC sample. The high reduction temperatures suggest the presence of a strong interaction between Ti-PILC and vanadia−ceria, which could inhibit the reducibility of vanadia or ceria. For the 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC sample (Fig. 7e), two separate reduction peaks appeared at 550 and 710°C, respectively, and the corresponding hydrogen consumption was 0.42mmol/g. The overlapped reduction peak in the range of 350−650°C was ascribed to the reduction of surface Ce4+ to Ce3+ and V5+ to V3+ as well as the reduction of the iron species, whereas the reduction peak at 710°C was due to the reduction of titania [27,30]. Additionally, as compared with the 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC sample, the TPR profile of the 2V4Ce/Ti-PILC sample (Fig. 7f) showed a progressive broadening of the peak and the peak shifted toward higher temperatures; the corresponding hydrogen consumption was 0.56mmol/g. With a rise in vanadia loading, a larger number of the surface V atoms interacted with the Ti-PILC support and ceria species, eventually resulting in a stronger interaction between the V or Ce species and the Ti-PILC support, which caused the broadening of the reduction peak and higher hydrogen consumption. To investigate the effect of Ti on the reducibility of yV4Ce/Ti-PILC, the Ti-free 1V4Ce/Clay sample was also prepared. Obviously, the TPR profile of the Ti-free 1V4Ce/Clay sample could be decomposed into two reduction peaks at 620 and 710°C (Fig. 7g), and the corresponding hydrogen consumption was 0.53mmol/g. The peak at 620°C was ascribed to the reduction of surface Ce4+, V5+, and iron species, while the peak at 710°C was due to the reduction of titania [27,30]. Compared with the reduction profiles of 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC, the peak temperature of the Ti-free 1V4Ce/Clay sample was higher. Hence, it is likely to have a cross-linking action between vanadia or ceria and Ti-PILC, which might facilitate the reduction of vanadia−ceria on the Ti-PILC support. 3.7 Surface element composition, metal oxidation state, and oxygen species In order to elucidate the surface nature of the active sites on the as-prepared samples, XPS analysis was carried out with an emphasis on the peaks associated with core-level O 1s, Ce 3d, and V 2p. The O 1s XPS spectra of the samples are shown in Fig. 8 A. Only one signal at binding energy (BE)=532.3eV was observed for the raw clay montmorillonite (Fig. 8A(a)), consistent with the BE (532.5±0.2eV) for the Si−O bonds in SiO2 (denoted as the surface O γ species) [31]. The content of SiO2 in montmorillonite was as high as 73.1wt%, and it was the main element of the montmorillonite (as confirmed by the XRF analysis). Therefore, the signal at BE=532.3eV was ascribed to the surface lattice oxygen for the Si−O bonds in montmorillonite. For the Ti-PILC sample (Fig. 8A(b)), the O 1s peak could be decomposed into two components, as denoted as the surface O α species (BE=530.5eV) and the surface O γ species (BE=532.4eV), respectively. The O α species corresponded to the lattice oxygen species of titania and the O γ species was assigned to the lattice oxygen species of the Si−O bonds in SiO2 [31,32]. For the 4Ce/Ti-PILC, 1V/Ti-PILC, 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC, and 2V4Ce/Ti-PILC samples, three types of oxygen species were clearly distinguished after deconvolution of the spectra. The component at BE=530.3−530.5eV was the surface lattice oxygen species (O α ) bound to metal cations, the component at BE=532.1−532.3eV was the surface chemisorbed oxygen species (O β , such as O2 −, O2 2−, O−, OH− or CO3 2−) on defect oxides, and the component at BE=532.4−532.7eV was the lattice oxygen species (O γ ) of the Si O bonds in SiO2 [31–33]. For the 1V4Ce/Clay sample, however, only two signals at BE=530.5 and 532.4eV were observed, which were the surface O α and O γ species, respectively. It has been reported that the surface chemisorbed oxygen (O β ) species favored the reduction of NO during the SCR process due to its higher mobility [32]. The amount of the oxygen species were calculated according to the relative areas of the peaks and the relative concentrations of O β /(O α + O β + O γ ) on the surface of various samples are summarized in Table 4 . It is found that the O β /(O α + O β + O γ ) concentration decreased in the order of 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC (51.8%)>4Ce/Ti-PILC (49.5%)>2V4Ce/Ti-PILC (49.3%)>1V/Ti-PILC (43.3%)>1V4Ce/Clay (0) ≈ Ti-PILC (0) ≈ Clay (0), in accordance with the sequence of their SCR performance. It is noticed that with the loading of ceria and/or vanadia, the peak area of O β obviously enlarged in comparison with montmorillonite or Ti-PILC. Moreover, the 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC sample with the highest chemisorbed oxygen amount showed higher NO conversions as compared with the other samples. The surface O β species were reported to be highly active for the NH3-SCR reaction [21,34]. The Ce 3d spectra of the samples are shown in Fig. 8B, in which each spectrum consisted of eight components. The peaks labeled uI and vI represented the 3d104f1 initial electronic state, corresponding to the surface Ce3+ species, while the presence of the 3d104f0 state of the surface Ce4+ species was confirmed by the peaks labeled u, uII, uIII, v, vII, and vIII [7,28]. These results demonstrate the co-existence of the surface Ce3+ and Ce4+ species on the samples, which was beneficial for generating advantageous charge imbalance to form oxygen vacancies, due to the fact that electron-trapping effect of oxygen vacancies made Ce4+ be reduced to Ce3+ [28]. The amounts of the surface Ce3+ and Ce4+ species on the samples were calculated from the relative areas of the corresponding peaks, as summarized in Table 4. It can be concluded from Table 4 that the surface Ce3+ molar ratio on the 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC sample was 40.5%, higher than that (30.5%) on the 4Ce/Ti-PILC sample, indicating the facilitated transformation of Ce4+ to Ce3+ induced by vanadia loading. Moreover, the intensity of Ce3+ characteristic peaks decreased with the rise in vanadia loading. This means that a portion of the surface Ce4+ species was inhibited to transform into the surface Ce3+ species due to the higher vanadia loading. The Ce3+/Ce4+ molar ratio decreased in the order of 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC (0.68)>4Ce/Ti-PILC (0.44)>2V4Ce/Ti-PILC (0.40)>1V4Ce/Clay (0.19). The existence of the surface Ce3+ species could create charge imbalance, oxygen vacancies, and unsaturated chemical bonds on the sample surface, leading to a more amount of the surface chemisorbed oxygen species on the 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC sample. Comparison with the Ti-free 1V4Ce/Clay sample, there was a much more amount of the surface Ce3+ species on 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC. Interestingly, we find that the NH3-SCR activity over the 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC sample with the highest Ce3+ concentration was the best, suggesting that the surface Ce3+ species played an important role in improving the catalytic performance of the sample. V 2p3/2 XPS spectra of 1V/Ti-PILC, 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC, 2V4Ce/Ti-PILC, and 1V4Ce/Clay are illustrated in Fig. 8C. The two peaks at BE=517 and 516.3eV indicate that the vanadium on the surface of the samples was present in V5+ (in majority) and V4+ (in minority) [35,36], respectively. Table 4 summarizes the molar ratios of V5+/V4+ in the samples estimated according to the aforementioned deconvolution method. The V5+/V4+ molar ratio increased from 4.0 for 1V/Ti-PILC to 6.4 for 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC. The result indicates that the surface Ce species could inhibit the reduction of V2O5 in the 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC sample owing to the interaction between vanadia and ceria. It can also be seen that the V5+/V4+ molar ratio increased from 6.4 for 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC to 11.7 for 2V4Ce/Ti-PILC. Meanwhile, the Ti-free 1V4Ce/Clay sample exhibited a lower V5+/V4+ molar ratio (2.7), as compared with that (6.4) on the 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC sample. The surface V5+/V4+ redox couple could transfer electrons to Ce4+, thus leading to Ce4+ →Ce3+, which might be one of the reasons for the high NO conversion in the NH3-SCR reaction over the yV4Ce/Ti-PILC samples. 3.8 NH3-TPD Acidity was one of the most important parameters and can be use to evaluate the extent of NO reduction with NH3 over the samples. The adsorption and activation of NH3 are usually used to determine the acidic sites of molecular sieve materials. NH3-TPD was performed to investigate the quantity of acidity and the acid strength, and the profiles are depicted in Fig. 9 . Only two desorption peaks was observed for the raw montmorillonite sample (Fig. 9a), whereas the other samples displayed three desorption peaks. The detailed peak positions and quantitative analysis results are listed in Table 5 . The first peak below 200°C was ascribed to the weak acidic sites, which corresponded to the desorption of the physisorbed ammonia and partially NH4 + bound to the weak Brønsted acid sites. The second one in the range of 207–257°C was related to the medium acid sites, which was due to the desorption of NH4 + from the strong Brønsted acid sites. The third one above 290°C was resulted from the coordinated NH3 bound to the Lewis acid sites [37]. As can be seen from Table 5, the NH3 desorption amount of the Ti-PILC sample was 12.51μmol/g, significantly higher than that (4.03μmol/g) of the raw montmorillonite sample. This result indicates that the total acidity was enhanced by pillaring the montmorillonite. It has been reported that the Ti-pillars were the main source of Lewis acid sites, while the Brønsted acid sites originated from the structural hydroxyl groups in the montmorillonite layer and TiO2 pillars [22,38]. Therefore, the Ti-pillars played a positive effect on the providing of acid sites (essentially the Lewis acid sites). When ceria was introduced on the surface of Ti-PILC (i.e., 4Ce/Ti-PILC), the amount of acidity at different locations further increased. It seems that the Ce species played a positive effect on the providing of numerous new acid sites. For the 1V/Ti-PILC sample, although the amount of the weak acid sites was increased, the quantity of strongly coordinated NH3-bound Lewis acid sites was reduced and the total acidity of 1V/Ti-PILC decreased. The change in the NH3-TPD profiles after vanadia addition could be explained by the fact that the strong acid sites arising from the Ti-pillars might be covered by the relatively weak acid sites arising from vanadia species [39]. NH3-TPD profiles of the yV4Ce/Ti-PILC samples are shown in Fig. 9e and f. Obviously, the drastic enhancement in total acidity of the yV4Ce/Ti-PILC samples was observed, as compared with that of the 4Ce/Ti-PILC or 1V/Ti-PILC sample. According to the amount of NH3 desorption, one can realize that the introduction of vanadia and ceria played a positive effect on the total amount of acid sites. Compared with the total acid quantity (16.32mmol/g) of 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC, that (18.03mmol/g) of 2V4Ce/Ti-PILC was obviously higher, attributable to the significant increase of vanadia loading. Although the total acid quantity of 2V4Ce/Ti-PILC was higher than that of 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC, the strong acid site quantity (8.13mmol/g) of the latter was considerably higher than that (5.6mmol/g) of 2V4Ce/Ti-PILC. The above results suggest that the vanadium species could produce weak acid sites while some of strong acid sites were covered by the excessive vanadium species [39]. To investigate the effect of Ti on the acid site of yV4Ce/Ti-PILC, the acid site quantity of the Ti-free 1V4Ce/Clay sample (Fig. 9g) was also compared. Apparently, the 1V4Ce/Clay sample possessed lower acid sites (5.78mmol/g), as compared with that of the 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC sample. The results further demonstrate that the Ti-pillars were the main source of acid sites, especially the strong acid sites. In the present study, the NH3 amount desorbed from the strong acid sites decreased in the sequence of 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC (8.13μmol/g)>4Ce/Ti-PILC (7.88μmol/g)>2V4Ce/Ti-PILC (5.60μmol/g)>1V/Ti-PILC (4.13μmol/g), correlating well with the order of their catalytic activities in the SCR reaction. The 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC sample showed the highest amount of strong acid sites, implying that the enhancement in acid site (especially strong site) was favorable for the NH3-SCR reaction. 3.9 DRIFTS-NH3 adsorption In situ DRIFT experiments were conducted over the raw clay montmorillonite and Ti-PILC and its supported vanadia or/and ceria samples to investigate the active sites, adsorbed species, and intermediates in/on the samples. Such important information can be used to clarify the adsorption and activation of the reactants, reaction pathways of the intermediates, and reaction mechanisms. Fig. 10 shows the DRIFT spectra of NH3 adsorption at 300°C on the samples. It is well known that NH3 could be adsorbed at the Brønsted or Lewis acid sites on the sample surface. As can bee seen from Fig. 10, several absorption bands at 3734, 3652, 3364, 3275, 1652, 1452, and 1180cm−1 were observed. In the low wavenumber range, the absorption bands at 1452 and 1652cm−1 were related to the NH4 + species on the Brønsted acid sites, and the one at 1180cm−1 was assigned to the NH3 species adsorbed on the Lewis acid sites [40]. In the high wavenumber range, the absorption bands at 3364 and 3275cm−1 were ascribed to the N−H stretching vibration mode of the coordinated NH3 bound to the Lewis acid sites, and the absorption band at 3734 and 3652cm−1 were attributed to the vibration of OH bound to the surface metal atoms [12,41]. The intensity of the peaks (3364, 3275, and 1180cm−1) ascribable to the adsorbed ammonia on the Lewis acid sites and of the ones (3652, 1652, and 1452cm−1) attributable to the adsorbed ammonia on the Brønsted acid sites of the Ti-PILC sample (Fig. 10b) was noticeably higher than that of the montmorillonite sample. By comparing the Ti-PILC (Fig. 10b) and montmorillonite samples (Fig. 10a), one can see that the Ti-pillars could increase the Brønsted and Lewis acidity, agreeing well with the results of the NH3-TPD study. The intensity of the absorption bands (3652 and 1652cm−1) assigned to the Brønsted acid sites and of the ones (3364, 3275, and 1180cm−1) ascribed to the Lewis acid sites of the 4Ce/Ti-PILC sample (Fig. 10c) was much higher than that of the Ti-PILC sample (Fig. 10b), suggesting that the loading of ceria could enhance the Brønsted and Lewis acid sites of the sample. These results were confirmed by the above NH3-TPD characterization. Compared with the Ti-PILC sample, however, the intensity of the absorption band (1652cm−1) assigned to the Brønsted acid sites and of the one (1180cm−1) attributed to the Lewis acid sites of the 1V/Ti-PILC sample (Fig. 10d) was much weaker. This observation was also in accordance with the NH3-TPD results discussed above (Fig. 9), which was likely due to the fact that some of the Brønsted and Lewis acid sites were covered by the vanadia species [39]. The intensity of the absorption bands at 1652cm−1 (assigned to the NH4 + species chemisorbed on the Brønsted acid sites) and 1180cm−1 (ascribed to the coordinated NH3 bound to the Lewis acid sites) of the yV4Ce/Ti-PILC samples (Fig. 10e and f) was higher than that of the vanadia or ceria-loaded sample, revealing that certain amounts of ceria and vanadia could enhance the activity of the Brønsted and Lewis acid sites. Furthermore, it is worth noting that the intensity of the absorption bands at 3734 and 3652cm−1 (assigned to the vibration of OH bound to the surface metal atoms) of the 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC sample was higher than that of the 2V4Ce/Ti-PILC sample, suggesting that a lower vanadia loading was beneficial for the enhancement in NH3 adsorption on the OH bound to the surface metal atoms. 3.10 In situ DRIFT spectroscopy 3.10.1 In situ DRIFT of NO+O2 co-adsorption Prior to the adsorption of NO+O2, the sample was pretreated in N2 (100mL/min) at 400°C for 2h. After the sample was cooled to 50°C, the N2 flow was switched to the 1000ppm NO+4 vol% O2 +N2 (balance) flow of 100mL/min, and in situ DRIFT spectra of the 4Ce/Ti-PILC and 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC samples were taken at different time, as shown in Fig. 11 A and B, respectively. Several distinct bands appeared at 1617–1618, 1558–1565, and 1301–1317cm−1, which were assigned to the bridged nitrates [40], bidentate nitrates [12,40], and monodentate nitrates [12], respectively. It is noted that the intensity of the band at 1617–1618, 1558–1565, and 1301–1317cm−1 was enhanced gradually with the increase in flow time. Compared with the co-adsorption of NO+O2 on the 4Ce/Ti-PILC sample, the intensity of the bands assigned to the monodentate nitrates (1317cm−1) was significantly increased on the 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC sample, indicating that the co-existence of vanadia–ceria contributed to formation of the monodentate nitrate species. 3.10.2 Reaction of NH3 with pre-adsorbed NO + O2 After the experiments of NO+O2 co-adsorption in Section 3.10.1, the N2 flow (100mL/min) was switched from the NO+O2 mixture to purge the 4Ce/Ti-PILC and 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC samples for 1h, then the N2 flow was switched to the 1100ppm NH3 +N2 (balance), and the in situ DRIFT spectra were taken at different time, as shown in Fig. 12 . For the 4Ce/Ti-PILC sample, the absorption band of the bridged nitrates at 1617cm−1 and the absorption band of bidentate nitrates at 1558 and 1301cm−1 were still observed after the co-adsorption of NO+O2 and the purging of N2. After NH3 introduction, the intensity of the absorption bands at 1617, 1558, and 1301cm−1 decreased rapidly with reaction time and they finally disappeared totally. The sample surface was mainly covered by the adsorbed NH3 species, including the NH3 (at 1250cm−1) adsorbed on the Lewis acid sites and NH4 + (at 1690 and 1474cm−1) bound to the Brønsted acid sites [41]. Furthermore, the appearance of the absorption band at 1101cm−1 indicates the oxidation of NH3 [41]. The change in the spectra of the 4Ce/Ti-PILC sample demonstrates the efficient reaction between the pre-adsorbed NO x species and adsorbed NH3, which obeyed the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism of the NH3-SCR reaction. For the 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC sample, the bridged nitrates (at 1618cm−1) and the bidentate nitrates (at 1565 and 1317cm−1) were also detected after the pre-adsorption of NO+O2 and the purging of N2; in the meanwhile, the adsorbed NO2 (at 1606cm−1) and free nitrate ions (at 1332cm−1) were also formed. The characteristic absorption bands of the adsorbed NO x species on 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC sample exhibited a significant decrease in intensity after the introduction of NH3. Moreover, it was reported that NO2 participated in the “fast SCR reaction”, which showed a higher reaction rate than the general “standard SCR” pathway [41]. The presence of the adsorbed NO2 (at 1606cm−1) on the 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC sample further promoted the NH3-SCR reaction via a “fast SCR” process. The “fast SCR” over the 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC sample played a significant role in promoting the whole SCR process, giving rise to a high catalytic activity. 3.10.3 In situ DRIFT of NH3 adsorption Prior to the adsorption of NH3, the 4Ce/Ti-PILC or 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC sample was pretreated in N2 (100mL/min) at 400°C for 2h. After the sample was cooled to 50°C, the N2 flow was switched to the mixed flow (100mL/min) of 1100ppm NH3 +N2 (balance). Fig. 13 shows the DRIFT spectra of NH3 adsorption on the 4Ce/Ti-PILC and 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC samples at different time. From Fig. 13A and B, one can see that the DRIFT spectra of NH3 adsorption on 4Ce/Ti-PILC were rather similar to those on 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC. The absorption bands at 931 and 967cm−1 were attributed to the weakly adsorbed or gas-phase ammonia [40], the absorption bands at 1095–1103 and 1253–1259cm−1 were assigned to the NH3 adsorbed on the Lewis acid sites, whereas the absorption bands at 1465–1475 and 1683–692cm−1 were attributed to the NH4 + bound to the Brønsted acid sites. In the high wavenumber range, the absorption band at 3257 − 3259cm−1 was referred to the NH3 adsorbed on the Lewis acid sites and the absorption band at 3400–3406cm−1 was ascribed to the NH2 groups [41]. The absorption band at 3619–3621cm−1 was assigned to the OH groups caused by the adsorption of NH4 + at the Brønsted acid sites. With an increase in exposure time, the intensity of all of the absorption bands increased markedly, indicating an enhancement in amount of the adsorbed NH3 species. Compared with the adsorption (at 1475 and 1692cm−1) of NH3 on the Brønsted acid sites of the 4Ce/Ti-PILC sample (Fig. 13A), the intensity of the adsorption (at 1465 and 1683cm−1) of NH3 on the Brønsted acid sites of the 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC sample were noticeably increased (Fig. 13B). This result implies that the number of the Brønsted acid sites of 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC was bigger than that of 4Ce/Ti-PILC. Since the NH4 + could take part in the SCR process, the proper proportion of the Brønsted acid sites might be responsible for the higher SCR activity of 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC. 3.10.4 Reaction of NO+O2 with pre-adsorbed NH3 After the experiments in section 3.10.3, the N2 flow (100mL/min) was switched from the mixed flow (100mL/min) of 1100ppm NH3 +N2 (balance) to purge the 4Ce/Ti-PILC or 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC sample for 1h, and then the N2 flow was switched to 1000ppm NO+O2. Fig. 14 shows the in situ DRIFT spectra of the 4Ce/Ti-PILC and 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC samples taken at different time. The weakly adsorbed or gas-phase ammonia (absorption bands at 996–998cm−1), NH3 adsorbed on the Lewis acid sites (absorption bands at 1093 –1097cm−1) and NH4 + ions located on Brønsted acidic sites (absorption bands at 1457−1462 and 1679–1683cm−1) were observed after NH3 adsorption and N2 purging. When NO+O2 was introduced, the acid strength was decreased slowly with the increase in exposure time, indicating that both NH4 + and NH3 had taken part in the SCR process over the 4Ce/Ti-PILC and 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC samples via the Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanism. Furthermore, the NH4 + species on the Brønsted acidic sites (absorption bands at 1457–1462 and 1679–1683cm−1) exhibited a faster consumption than the NH3 species on the Lewis acid sites (absorption band at 1093–1097cm−1). The excess introduction of NO+O2 resulted in the formation and accumulation of nitrate species on the sample surface, leading to the appearance of the bridged nitrates (absorption band at 1622 –1625cm−1). 4 Discussion Based on the results of sample characterization and activity evaluation, the reasons for the increase of catalytic activity of the V-Ce/Ti-PILC samples could be explained as follows: H2-TPR (Fig. 7 and Table 2) results revealed a strong interaction between ceria and vanadia, which gave rise to the increased H2 consumption and high-temperature reduction. Analysis results of XPS studies (Fig. 8 and Table 4) demonstrated that there were V5+/V4+ and Ce4+/Ce3+ redox cycles on the surface of the V-Ce/Ti-PILC samples and the existence of V5+/V4+ could promote the redox process of Ce4+ ↔ Ce3+. Therefore, the redox cycle (V4+ +Ce4+ ↔V5+ +Ce3+) existed on the surface of V–Ce/Ti-PILC and the electron transfer could be facilitated: V5+–O2––Ce4+ +e↔V4+–O2––Ce4+ ↔V5+ –O2– –Ce3+ ↔ V5+ –O2– –Ce4+ +e. Furthermore, the XPS results showed that the proper addition of vanadia promoted formation of the Ce3+ species on the 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC sample. The presence of Ce3+ could induce formation of a more amount of the chemisorbed oxygen (O β ) species, which was beneficial for the NH3-SCR reaction. Liu et al. [12] pointed out that the chemisorbed oxygen was one of the most active oxygen species and played a critical role in the oxidation of NO to NO2. NO2 is easier to form nitrates that could react with the adsorbed NH3 on the Lewis acid sites or the adsorbed NH4 + on the Brønstred acid sites, resulting in a significant increase in NO conversion of NH3-SCR via the enhanced “fast SCR” reaction. The NH3-TPD (Fig. 9 and Table 5) and DRIFTS-NH3 (Fig. 10) adsorption results showed that the 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC sample possessed high acidity and high NH3 adsorption ability, which were responsible for the high NO conversions in the wide range of temperatures. As for the NH3-SCR reaction mechanism, the in situ DRIFT techniques were used to investigate the absorption of NH3 and NO and their surface reactions on the 4Ce/Ti-PILC and 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC samples. NO could first be adsorbed on the surface of the 4Ce/Ti-PILC and 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC samples in the form of nitrates (Fig. 11), then the intensity of absorption bands due to nitrate species decreased rapidly and they disappeared totally with an increase in time of NH3 exposure (Fig. 12), and finally the sample surface was mainly covered by the adsorbed NH3 species. The changes in spectra of the 4Ce/Ti-PILC and 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC samples revealed the efficient reaction between the pre-adsorbed NO x and adsorbed NH3 species, which indicates that the NH3-SCR reaction obeyed a Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L−H) mechanism over 4Ce/Ti-PILC and 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC. The presence of adsorbed NO2 (absorption band at 1606cm−1) on the 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC sample promoted the NH3-SCR activity via the “fast SCR” process. On the other hand, NH3 could first be adsorbed on both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites on the 4Ce/Ti-PILC and 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC samples (Fig. 13), and then reacted with gas-phase NO. As a result, the corresponding absorption bands in the in situ DRIFT spectra (Fig. 14) slowly decreased in intensity when the samples pretreated with NH3 were exposed to the NO+O2 mixture. Therefore, an Eley−Rideal (E−R) mechanism of the NH3-SCR reaction could also exist on the 4Ce/Ti-PILC and 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC samples. On the basis of the above discussion, the reaction of NH3 with the pre-adsorbed NO+O2 was rapid, whereas the reaction of NO+O2 with the pre-adsorbed NH3 was slow over the 4Ce/Ti-PILC and 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC samples. Hence, it can be concluded that the NH3-SCR reaction over the 4Ce/Ti-PILC and 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC samples obeyed both L−H and E−R mechanisms, with the L-H mechanism being dominant. 5 Conclusions A series of the V-Ce/Ti-PILC samples could be prepared using the impregnation method. Among the as-prepared samples, 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC exhibited the best catalytic activity for the SCR of NO with NH3 (above 90% NO conversion in a broad operating temperature window of 280–450°C). The vanadia was uniformly dispersed on Ti-PILC, whereas the ceria was mainly the crystalline CeO2 phase. The Ti-pillared support was beneficial for the dispersion of vanadia–ceria. There was a strong interaction between ceria and vanadia, which resulted in increased H2 consumption and high-temperature reduction. The enhanced performance stemmed from the existed redox cycle (V4+ +Ce4+ ↔V5+ +Ce3+). Furthermore, the proper loading of vanadia could promote formation of the Ce3+ species on the surface of 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC. The presence of Ce3+ could induce formation of a more amount of the chemisorbed oxygen (O β ) species, which favored the NH3-SCR reaction. The NH3-TPD and DRIFTS-NH3 characterization results showed that the acidity on the surface of 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC played an important role in enhancing the NH3-SCR performance. The in situ DRIFT spectra demonstrated that the NH3-SCR reaction over the 4Ce/Ti-PILC and 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC samples obeyed both L−H and E−R mechanisms, in which the former was dominant. coredata.dc:description: The Ti-pillared clay-supported vanadia−ceria (yV4Ce/Ti-PILC, y was the V weight percentage (wt%), Ce weight percentage=4wt%) samples were prepared using the impregnation method. The catalytic activity for the selective catalytic reduction of NO x with NH3 (NH3-SCR) decreased in the order of 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC >4Ce/Ti-PILC >2V4Ce/Ti-PILC >1V/Ti-PILC >1V4Ce/Clay > Ti-PILC > Clay, with the 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC sample exhibiting the best activity (NO x conversion >90% at 280–450°C). Physiochemical properties of the samples were investigated by means of XRD, N2 absorption-desorption, SEM, H2-TPR, NH3-TPD, XPS, and in situ DRIFT techniques. The vanadia was uniformly dispersed on the Ti-PILC support, while the ceria were mainly present in CeO2. The Ti-pillared support was suitable for dispersing the V-Ce composite oxides. The strong interaction between vanadia and ceria led to increased H2 consumption and high-temperature reduction. The Ce4+/Ce3+ and V5+/V4+ redox cycle (V4+ +Ce4+ ↔V5+ +Ce3+) accounted for the excellent NH3-SCR catalytic performance of the 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC sample. The doping of a proper amount of vanadia could promote formation of Ce3+ on the surface of 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC, and the formed Ce3+ could generate a more amount of the chemisorbed oxygen species that favored the NH3-SCR reaction. Furthermore, the 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC sample possessed high catalytic acidity and strong NH3 adsorption ability, which were responsible for high NO conversion in a wide range of temperatures. The NH3-SCR reaction on the 4Ce/Ti-PILC and 1V4Ce/Ti-PILC samples obeyed the Langmuir–Hinshelwood (L–H) and Eley-Rideal (E–R) mechanisms, with the former being dominant.
